revision.text:
{{orphan|date=May 2017}}
'''Charles Patrick Dunphey''' (born November 22, 1992) is an American [[author]] from [[Staten Island, New York]] who lives in [[southern Mississippi]].
His debut work, a [[science fiction]] [[horror novel]] titled ''[[Plane Walker]]'', was released in April 2016. Dunphey is also a [[film reviewer]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Charles Dunphey |url=http://charlesdunphey.blogspot.com/ |title=Charles Dunphey (Author) |publisher=Charlesdunphey.blogspot.com |date=2014-11-13 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> and founder of Gehenna and Hinnom Books.
Dunphey holds a [[Bachelor's degree|bachelor's]] in [[English literature|English]] from the [[University of Southern Mississippi]].
== Early life == C. P. Dunphey was born in Staten Island, New York before moving to [[Brooklyn, New York]]. After his father received a job offer in Mississippi, Dunphey and his family moved to [[Meridian, Mississippi]] before settling in [[Picayune, Mississippi]]. From a very young age, Dunphey was fascinated with science fiction and [[Horror fiction|horror]], often filling composition notebooks front to back with [[space opera]]s and horror stories.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://house-of-books.com/2016/07/author-interview-c-p-dunphey/ |title=AUTHOR INTERVIEW – C.P. Dunphey – Shannon Muir's Infinite House of Books |publisher=House-of-books.com |date=2016-07-18 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> He was diagnosed with [[Bipolar Disorder]] at a very young age, often citing this disease as the source of his creativity.<ref name="jscottcoatsworth1">{{cite web|author=Theme: Catch Flames by |url=https://www.jscottcoatsworth.com/author-spotlight-c-p-dunphey/ |title=Author Spotlight: C.P. Dunphey – J. Scott Coatsworth |publisher=Jscottcoatsworth.com |date=2017-02-05 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> After graduating from [[Picayune Memorial High School]], Dunphey would attend [[Pearl River Community College]] in [[Poplarville, Mississippi]] where he would receive his [[Associate degree|Associate's in Arts]]. Then he moved to [[Hattiesburg, Mississippi]] and received his Bachelor's in English from the University of Southern Mississippi.
== Writing career == C. P. Dunphey's first credited publication was in December 2012 when he was 19 years old.<ref>{{cite web|author=11:22 a.m. CT April 16, 2016 |url=http://www.hattiesburgamerican.com/story/life/2016/04/16/dunphey-hopes-book-takes-readers-another-world/82958640/ |title=Dunphey hopes book takes readers to another world |publisher=Hattiesburgamerican.com |date=2016-04-16 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> The novel titled ''Lazarus'', which would evolve into ''Plane Walker'' four years later, was released independently, self-published through [[Amazon.com|Amazon's]] subsidiary company [[CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform|Createspace]]. Dunphey has expressed that he wasn't necessarily proud of this work, citing many different reasons. According to an interview with Dunphey on J. Scott Coatsworth's blog, Dunphey called the first book "rushed" and "lacking of patience" in narrative.<ref name="jscottcoatsworth1"/> From 2012-2016, Dunphey worked on the manuscript he originally published and ended up adding over a hundred pages of content while also having the manuscript undergo extensive edits and reconstruction. The publication of ''Plane Walker'' and the formation of Gehenna Publishing House followed a period in Dunphey's life where he was practically homeless, inciting a desire for change in him that led to his dedication to his writing.<ref>{{cite web|author=Posted by C. P. Dunphey on July 5, 2016 at 9:42pm View Blog |url=http://thebookmarketingnetwork.com/profiles/blogs/from-living-in-shambles-to-becoming-a-published-author-and |title=From Living in Shambles to Becoming a Published Author and Founder of a Publishing House by C. P. Dunphey |publisher=The Book Marketing Network |date=2016-07-05 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref>
Dunphey had also been published in columns of the [[comic books]] ''[[Haunt (comics)|Haunt]]'' and ''[[Spawn (comics)|Spawn]]'', though these were merely guest [[interviews]] concerning the plots and characters of the series where he was able to speak with such writers and artists as [[Todd McFarlane]] and [[Greg Capullo]], respectively.
In April 2016, the finished product of ''Plane Walker'' was released on Amazon through Dunphey's small press, Gehenna Publishing House (also known as Gehenna & Hinnom Books). The novel received primarily positive reviews, Dunphey's writing being compared to that of [[Thomas Ligotti]], [[H.P. Lovecraft]], [[Philip K. Dick]], and [[John Carpenter]], among others.<ref>{{cite web|last=Anderson |first=Stuart |url=http://stuart66.blogspot.com/2016/09/plane-walker-novel-by-cp-dunphey.html |title=5D. The Fifth Dimension: Plane Walker - A novel by C.P Dunphey |publisher=Stuart66.blogspot.com |date=2016-09-17 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> Dunphey's [[Philosophical literature|philosophical]] and often [[poetic language]] has been the center of most discussion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://donovansliteraryservices.com/february-2017-lp.html |title=February 2017 Prime Picks - Donovan's Bookshelf |publisher=Donovansliteraryservices.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> On the contrary, veteran science fiction magazine ''[[Amazing Stories]]'' felt the novel was "slow to start" and that it "focuses too much on minutia" even if work itself was "well-written."<ref>{{cite web|author=Jack Hillman |url=http://amazingstoriesmag.com/2016/12/plane-walker-review/ |title=Plane Walker Review - Amazing Stories |publisher=Amazingstoriesmag.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref>
''Plane Walker'' became a [[Reader's Favorite|Five Star Reader's Favorite]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://readersfavorite.com/book-review/plane-walker |title=Book review of Plane Walker - Readers' Favorite: Book Reviews and Award Contest |publisher=Readersfavorite.com |date=2016-04-22 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> a Pitch Perfect Pick winner on Underground Book Reviews,<ref>{{cite web|author=Name * |url=https://www.undergroundbookreviews.org/this-weeks-pitch-perfect-pick-24/ |title=Underground Book Reviews – This Week’s Pitch Perfect Pick |publisher=Undergroundbookreviews.org |date=2017-01-16 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> was nominated for the [[The Eric Hoffer Award|Eric Hoffer Award]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/Cpdunphey/photos/a.208398309299966.50941.156135521192912/862909327182191/?type=3&theater |title=Plane Walker is officially nominated in... - C. P. Dunphey - Author |publisher=Facebook |date=2017-01-20 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> and became a [[bestseller]] on Amazon in the genre of [[Hard science fiction|Hard Science fiction]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/gehennapublishinghouse/posts/941654572599187 |title=Friends, please share this and help... - Gehenna & Hinnom Books |publisher=Facebook |date=2016-04-21 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> in May 2016.
In 2017, Dunphey has several upcoming [[short stories]] announced to be published in [[anthologies]]. Most notably, the Lovecraft Lunatic Asylum's [[anthology series]] is publishing two of Dunphey's stories in two separate anthologies, set for release in mid-2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/pg/Cpdunphey/posts/ |title=C. P. Dunphey - Author - Posts |publisher=Facebook |date= |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> Dunphey also announced on [[social media]] in late-2016 that he plans to release the [[sequel]] to ''Plane Walker'' along with a short story collection by the end of the year.
== Influences == C. P. Dunphey has cited several authors of being [[wikt:inspiration|inspiration]]s to him as an author. Most notably, he has called H.P. Lovecraft his favorite author while stating [[Frank Herbert]]'s ''[[Dune (novel)|Dune]]'' as his favorite novel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://house-of-books.com/2016/07/author-interview-c-p-dunphey |title=AUTHOR INTERVIEW – C.P. Dunphey – Shannon Muir's Infinite House of Books |publisher=House-of-books.com |date=2016-07-18 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> Other inspirations that have been mentioned are H.P. Lovecraft, Thomas Ligotti, [[Stephen King]], [[J.R.R. Tolkien]], and others.<ref name="jscottcoatsworth1"/> Readers and reviewers have described Dunphey's style as poetic and [[Lyric poetry|lyrical]] while maintaining a horror and science fiction scope. Dunphey is also a self-proclaimed science fiction and horror [[Nut (disambiguation)|nut]], finding inspiration for his writing in such films as ''[[Event Horizon (film)|Event Horizon]]'', ''[[The Texas Chain Saw Massacre]]'', ''[[Jacob's Ladder (1990 film)|Jacob's Ladder]]'', ''[[Alien (franchise)|The Alien Franchise]]'', ''[[Terminator (franchise)|The Terminator Franchise]]'', and [[video game series]] such as ''[[Dead Space (series)|Dead Space]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Anderson |first=Stuart |url=http://stuart66.blogspot.com/2016/07/guest-blog-3-from-texas-chain-saw.html |title=5D. The Fifth Dimension: Guest Blog #3 - From The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (1974) to Plane Walker – How Senses Can Shape a Narrative by C. P. Dunphey |publisher=Stuart66.blogspot.com |date=2016-07-08 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref>
== Gehenna Publishing House/Gehenna & Hinnom books ==
In November 2015, C. P. Dunphey founded the company Gehenna Publishing House with the hopes of reaching out to and signing authors from the [[southeastern United States]], having felt they were [[underrated]] and generally unspoken for.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/209192307/ |title=Columbian-Progress from Columbia, Mississippi on February 25, 2016 · Page 06 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=2016-02-25 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> Signing on several authors within the first few months, the company quickly became too much for Dunphey to maintain on his own as he tried to helm the entire company by himself, stating this on social media in late 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/gehennapublishinghouse/photos/a.808519209246058.1073741830.808506135914032/1017344461696864/?type=3&theater |title=For the time being, Gehenna Publishing... - Gehenna & Hinnom Books |publisher=Facebook |date=2016-08-21 |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> Since then, the company has formed into Gehenna & Hinnom Books, a [[small press]] still operated by Dunphey with the hopes to provide [[Classic literature|classic works]] of science fiction and horror to [[Children's literature|young readers]].
In April 2017, Gehenna & Hinnom Books revealed a call for submissions on their new site.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/04/03/call-for-submissions-visceral-horror-anthology-years-best-body-horror/|title=Call for Submissions — Visceral Horror Anthology, "Year’s Best Body Horror"|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=3 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref> The topic of the anthology will be [[body horror]] and the expected release date is November 2017, with the tentative title, ''Year's Best Body Horror 2017 Anthology''. In celebration of the genre, Gehenna & Hinnom started a review series of films and novels within the subgenre of [[Body horror|visceral horror]], their first reviews being for the 2016 Science fiction horror film, ''[[The Void (2016 film)|The Void]]'', and the 2016 horror film, ''[[The Eyes of My Mother]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/04/11/body-horror-review-series-chapter-1-the-void-2016/|title=The Void (2016): Body Horror Review Series Chapter 1|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=11 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/04/17/the-eyes-of-my-mother-2016-body-horror-review-series-chapter-2/|title=The Eyes of My Mother (2016): Body Horror Review Series Chapter 2|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=17 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref> The publisher also announced the upcoming release of an interview with Lovecraft scholar, [[S.T. Joshi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/04/04/when-we-get-1000-views-s-t-joshi-interview-will-be-uploaded/|title=When We Get 1,000 Views, S.T. Joshi Interview Will Be Uploaded|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=4 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
On April 29, 2017, The Gehenna Post released a review for the 2016 film, ''[[The Girl with All the Gifts (film)|The Girl With all the Gifts]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/04/29/the-girl-with-all-the-gifts-2016-body-horror-review-series-chapter-3/|title=The Girl With All The Gifts (2016): Body Horror Review Series Chapter 3|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=29 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
On May 1, 2017, the interview with [[Lovecraft]] scholar, [[S.T. Joshi]], titled, "Questions over [[Innsmouth]]," was released.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/05/01/questions-over-innsmouth-interview-with-lovecraftian-scholar-s-t-joshi/|title=Questions Over Innsmouth: Interview with Lovecraftian Scholar S.T. Joshi|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=1 May 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
On May 28, Gehenna & Hinnom announced a submissions call for a new anthology, tentatively titled, ''Year's Best Transhuman SF 2017 Anthology''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/05/28/call-for-submissions-science-fiction-anthology-years-best-transhuman-sf/|title=Call for Submissions — Science Fiction Anthology, "Year’s Best Transhuman SF"|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=28 May 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
On June 30, Gehenna & Hinnom released the first issue of their magazine series, ''Hinnom Magazine'', featuring stories of horror, fantasy, science fiction, a film review of ''[[Alien: Covenant]]'' and the interview with S.T. Joshi.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/06/21/christmas-has-come-early-hinnom-magazine-001/|title=Christmas Has Come Early – Hinnom Magazine 001|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=21 June 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
On July 28, The Gehenna Post interviewed dark fiction author, T.E. Grau.
On August 31, the second volume of ''Hinnom Magazine'' will be released.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/08/10/hinnom-magazine-002-cover-reveal-and-table-of-contents/|title=HINNOM MAGAZINE 002 Cover Reveal and Table of Contents|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=10 August 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
Between August 2, and August 4, The Gehenna post reviewed the [[short film]] anthology from [[Oats Studios]] of which [[South African]] director [[Neill Blomkamp]] was the helm.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/08/02/oats-studios-volume-1-rakka-a-gehenna-post-review/|title=OATS STUDIOS – VOLUME 1: Rakka — A Gehenna Post Review|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=3 August 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/08/03/oats-studios-volume-1-firebase-a-gehenna-post-review/|title=OATS STUDIOS — VOLUME 1: Firebase — A Gehenna Post Review|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=3 August 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/08/04/oats-studios-volume-1-zygote-a-gehenna-post-review/|title=OATS STUDIOS — Volume 1: Zygote — A Gehenna Post Review|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=4 August 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
On August 10, Gehenna & Hinnom announced their [[Body horror|Body Horror]] Anthology as releasing on September 30 of 2017, along with the [[table of contents]] and the cover reveal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/08/09/body-horror-anthology-reveal-cover-release-date-and-table-of-contents/|title=BODY HORROR ANTHOLOGY REVEAL: Cover, Release Date, and Table of Contents|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=10 August 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
On August 16, the Gehenna Post reviewed the 2017 [[horror film]], [[Annabelle: Creation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gehennaandhinnom.wordpress.com/2017/08/16/annabelle-creation-a-gehenna-post-review/|title=ANNABELLE: CREATION — A Gehenna Post Review|first=|last=Gehennaandhinnom|date=16 August 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dunphey, CP}} [[Category:American science fiction writers]] [[Category:American horror writers]] [[Category:Writers from New York (state)]] [[Category:People from Staten Island]] [[Category:Transhumanism]] [[Category:Pearl River Community College alumni]] [[Category:University of Southern Mississippi alumni]] [[Category:1992 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Picayune, Mississippi]]

The '''Carter–Menil Human Rights Prize''' was established in 1986 by former [[United States president]] [[Jimmy Carter]] and US philanthropist [[Dominique de Menil]] to "promote the protection of [[human rights]] throughout the world."<ref>[http://www.cartercenter.org/news/documents/doc181.html#menil The Carter-Menil Human Rights Foundation Award description] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603034653/http://www.cartercenter.org/news/documents/doc181.html#menil |date=June 3, 2009 }}</ref> The foundation periodically gives out prizes of $100,000 to individuals and institutions that promote human rights. Carter is the chairman of the Prize Committee.
==See also== * [[Carter Center]] * [[Jimmy Carter]]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081204154912/http://www.cartercenter.org/news/documents/doc181.html Official Prize page with partial list of recipients]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Jimmy Carter}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Carter-Menil Human Rights Prize}} [[Category:Human rights awards]] [[Category:Jimmy Carter]]

page.title: Chief Whip of the Labour Party

revision.comment: Adding template in similar form to that already on the Conservative whips page, and correcting a date.
revision.text:
The '''Chief Whip of the Labour Party''' is responsible for administering the [[Whip (politics)|whipping system]] in the party which ensures that members attend and vote in [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|parliament]] when the [[Leader of the Labour Party (UK)|party leadership]] requires a majority vote. Whips, of which two are appointed in the party, a member of the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] and a member of the [[House of Lords]] also help to organise their party’s contribution to parliamentary business. On some occasions, the party leadership may allow MP's to have a [[Conscience vote|free vote]] based on their own conscience rather than party policy, of which the chief whip is not required to direct votes. This is a list of those people who have served as [[Chief Whip]] of the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] in the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]]. ==House of Commons== {{Infobox Political post |post = Chief Whip of the

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} A '''colonial mentality''' is the [[Internalized oppression|internalized]] attitude of ethnic or cultural inferiority felt by people as a result of [[colonization]], i.e. them being colonized by another group.Nunning, Vera. (06/01/2015). Fictions of Empire and the (un-making of imperialist mentalities: Colonial discourse and post-colonial criticism revisited. Forum for world literature studies. (7)2. p.171-198. It corresponds with the belief that the cultural values of the colonizer are inherently superior to one's own.{{Cite journal|last=David|first=E. J. R.|last2=Okazaki|first2=Sumie|date=2010-04-01|title=Activation and Automaticity of Colonial Mentality|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1559-1816.2010.00601.x/abstract|journal=Journal of Applied Social Psychology|language=en|volume=40|issue=4|pages=850|doi=10.1111/j.1559-1816.2010.00601.x|issn=1559-1816|via=}} The term has been used by [[Postcolonialism|postcolonial]] scholars to discuss the [[Transgenerational trauma|transgenerational]] effects of colonialism present in former colonies following [[decolonization]].{{Cite journal|last=David|first=E. J. R.|title=Testing the validity of the colonial mentality implicit association test and the interactive effects of covert and overt colonial mentality on Filipino American mental health.|url=http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/a0018820|journal=[[Asian American Journal of Psychology]]|language=en|volume=1|issue=1|pages=31–45|doi=10.1037/a0018820}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/757835774|title=Unconscious dominions : psychoanalysis, colonial trauma, and global sovereignties|date=2011|publisher=Duke University Press|others=Anderson, Warwick, 1958-, Jenson, Deborah., Keller, Richard C. (Richard Charles), 1969-|isbn=9780822393986|location=Durham, NC|oclc=757835774}} It is commonly used as an operational concept for framing ideological domination in historical colonial experiences.{{Cite journal|last=Goss|first=Andrew|date=2009|title=Decent colonialism? Pure science and colonial ideology in the Netherlands East Indies, 1910–1929|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-southeast-asian-studies/article/decent-colonialism-pure-science-and-colonial-ideology-in-the-netherlands-east-indies-19101929/BC7B305D4BD58EAB5093B5536A767275|journal=Journal of Southeast Asian Studies|volume=40|issue=1|pages=187–214|doi=10.1017/s002246340900006x|issn=1474-0680|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Felipe|first=Lou Collette S.|title=The relationship of colonial mentality with Filipina American experiences with racism and sexism.|url=http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/aap0000033|journal=[[Asian American Journal of Psychology]]|language=en|volume=7|issue=1|pages=25–30|doi=10.1037/aap0000033}} In [[psychology]] colonial mentality has been used to explain instances of [[collective depression]], [[anxiety]], and other widespread [[Mental disorder|mental health]] issues in populations that have experienced colonization.{{Cite journal|last=Paranjpe|first=Anand C.|date=2016-08-11|title=Indigenous Psychology in the Post- Colonial Context: An Historical Perspective|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/097133360201400103|journal=Psychology and Developing Societies|language=en|volume=14|issue=1|pages=27–43|doi=10.1177/097133360201400103}}{{Cite journal|last=Utsey|first=Shawn O.|last2=Abrams|first2=Jasmine A.|last3=Opare-Henaku|first3=Annabella|last4=Bolden|first4=Mark A.|last5=Williams|first5=Otis|date=2014-05-21|title=Assessing the Psychological Consequences of Internalized Colonialism on the Psychological Well-Being of Young Adults in Ghana|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0095798414537935|journal=Journal of Black Psychology|language=en|volume=41|issue=3|pages=195–220|doi=10.1177/0095798414537935}} Notable [[Marxism|Marxist]] influences on the postcolonial concept of colonial mentality include [[Frantz Fanon|Frantz Fanon's]] works on the fracturing of the colonial psyche through Western cultural domination,{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/461323889|title=Forms of Fanonism : Frantz Fanon's critical theory and the dialectics of decolonization|last=1972-|first=Rabaka, Reiland,|date=2010|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=9780739140338|location=Lanham, Md.|oclc=461323889}} as well as the concept of [[cultural hegemony]] developed by [[Italian Communist Party]] Founder [[Antonio Gramsci]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/749115630|title=The postcolonial Gramsci|date=2012|publisher=Routledge|others=Srivastava, Neelam Francesca Rashmi, 1972-, Bhattacharya, Baidik, 1975-|isbn=9780415874816|location=New York|oclc=749115630}}{{toclimit|3}} == Influences from Marxism == === Frantz Fanon === Frantz Fanon's Marxist writings on [[imperialism]], [[racism]], and decolonizing struggles have influenced post-colonial discussions about the internalization of colonial prejudice. Fanon first tackled the problem of, what he called, the "colonial alienation of the person"{{Cite book|title=Black Skin, White Masks|last=Fanon|first=Frantz|publisher=Pluto Press|year=2008|isbn=978 0 7453 2849 2|location=London, United Kingdom|pages=xxiii}} as a mental health issue through [[Psychiatric assessment|psychiatric]] analysis.{{Cite journal|last=Robertson|first=Michael|last2=Walter|first2=Garry|date=2009|title=Frantz Fanon and the confluence of psychiatry, politics, ethics and culture|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/acta-neuropsychiatrica/article/frantz-fanon-and-the-confluence-of-psychiatry-politics-ethics-and-culture/CBD3BF91C1D4CCE616DA14F16D492697|journal=Acta Neuropsychiatrica|volume=21|issue=6|pages=308–309|doi=10.1111/j.1601-5215.2009.00428.x|issn=0924-2708|via=}} In ''[[The Wretched of the Earth]]'' ([[French language|French]]: ''Les Damnés de la Terre),'' published in 1961, Fanon used psychiatry to analyze how [[French Algeria|French colonization]] and the carnage of the [[Algerian War]] had mentally affected Algerians' [[National identity|self-identity]] and mental health.{{Cite journal|last=Bell|first=Vikki|date=2011-01-04|title=Introduction: Fanon’s The Wretched of the Earth 50 Years On|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0263276410383721|journal=Theory, Culture & Society|language=en|volume=27|issue=7-8|pages=7–14|doi=10.1177/0263276410383721}} The book argues that during the period of colonization there was a subtle and constant mental pathology that developed within the colonial psyche.{{Cite book|url=http://abahlali.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Frantz-Fanon-The-Wretched-of-the-Earth-1965.pdf|title=The Wretched of the Earth|last=Fanon|first=Frantz|publisher=Grove Press, Inc|others=Sartre, Jean-Paul, 1905-1980, Farrington, Constance,|year=1961|isbn=0802150837|location=New York|pages=250|oclc=1316464}} Fanon argued that the colonial psyche is fractured by the lack of mental and material homogeneity as a result of the colonial power's [[Western culture]] being pressured onto the colonized population despite the existing material differences between them.{{Cite book|url=http://abahlali.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Frantz-Fanon-The-Wretched-of-the-Earth-1965.pdf|title=The Wretched of the Earth|last=Fanon|first=Frantz|publisher=Grove Press, Inc|others=Sartre, Jean-Paul, 1905-1980, Farrington, Constance,|year=1961|isbn=0802150837|location=New York|pages=194|oclc=1316464}} Here Fanon expands traditional Marxist understandings of [[historical materialism]] to explore how the dissonance between [[Base and superstructure|material existence and culture]] functions to transform the colonized people through the mold of the Western [[bourgeoisie]].{{Cite book|url=http://abahlali.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Frantz-Fanon-The-Wretched-of-the-Earth-1965.pdf|title=The Wretched of the Earth|last=Fanon|first=Frantz|publisher=Grove Press, Inc|others=Sartre, Jean-Paul, 1905-1980, Farrington, Constance,|year=1961|isbn=0802150837|location=New York|pages=162|oclc=1316464}} This meant that the native Algerian came to view their own traditional culture and identity through the lens of colonial prejudice. Fanon observed that average Algerians internalized and then openly repeated remarks that were in line with the institutionalized racist culture of the French colonizers; dismissing their own culture as backward due to the internalization of Western colonial ideologies.{{Cite book|url=http://abahlali.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Frantz-Fanon-The-Wretched-of-the-Earth-1965.pdf|title=The Wretched of the Earth|last=Fanon|first=Frantz|publisher=Grove Press, Inc|others=Sartre, Jean-Paul, 1905-1980, Farrington, Constance,|year=1961|isbn=0802150837|location=New York|pages=161|oclc=1316464}} According to Fanon this results in a destabilizing existential conflict within the colonized culture:
"In [[Western world|the West]], the family circle, the effects of education, and the relatively high [[standard of living]] of the working class provide a more or less efficient protection against the harmful action of these pastimes. But in an African country, where mental development is uneven, where the violent collision of two worlds has considerably shaken old traditions and thrown the universe of the perceptions out of focus, the impressionability and sensibility of the Young African are at the mercy of the various assaults made upon them by the very Nature of Western Culture."{{Cite book|url=http://abahlali.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Frantz-Fanon-The-Wretched-of-the-Earth-1965.pdf|title=The Wretched of the Earth|last=Fanon|first=Frantz|publisher=Grove Press, Inc|others=Sartre, Jean-Paul, 1905-1980, Farrington, Constance,|year=1961|isbn=0802150837|location=New York|pages=194–195|oclc=1316464}}
==British India== [[File:British india.JPG|thumb|Territorial extent of British India.]] During the period of the [[British Raj]], proponents of [[British Empire|British Imperialism]] typically regarded native [[Indian culture]] with disdain and supported European colonization as a beneficial "[[civilizing mission]]".{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/10.1007/978-3-319-13638-7|title=Cultural Heritage as Civilizing Mission {{!}} SpringerLink|last=Falser|first=Michael|publisher=Cham: Springer|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=8–9|language=en-gb|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-13638-7}} Colonization was largely framed as an act of charity aimed at uplifting the "uncivilized" Indian, rather than an act of direct exploitation and domination; which targeted native cultural practices deemed to be "barbaric" by colonial administrators.{{Cite journal|last=Fischer–Tiné|first=Harald|date=2016-07-26|title=Britain's other civilising mission|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/001946460504200302|journal=The Indian Economic & Social History Review|language=en|volume=42|issue=3|pages=295–338|doi=10.1177/001946460504200302}} For example, the colonial policies barring the self-immolating practice of [[Sati (practice)|sati]],{{Cite journal|last=Mukta|first=Parita|title=The ‘Civilizing Mission’: The Regulation and Control of Mourning in Colonial India|url=http://www.palgrave-journals.com/doifinder/10.1080/014177899339045|journal=Feminist Review|volume=63|issue=1|pages=25–47|doi=10.1080/014177899339045}} and the influence of British [[missionaries]] in discouraging perceived acts of [[idolatry]],{{Cite journal|last=Ganguly|first=Swagato|date=2017-01-02|title=Idolatry: concept and metaphor in colonial representations of India|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/19472498.2016.1260353|journal=South Asian History and Culture|volume=8|issue=1|pages=19–91|doi=10.1080/19472498.2016.1260353|issn=1947-2498}} the latter of which has been noted by some scholars to have played a large role in the developments of the modern definition of [[History of Hinduism|Hinduism]].{{Cite book|url=http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/view/10.1093/0195166558.001.0001/acprof-9780195166552|title=Was Hinduism Invented?: Britons, Indians, and the Colonial Construction of Religion - Oxford Scholarship|last=Pennington|first=Brian K.|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2005|isbn=0195166558|location=|pages=|language=en|doi=10.1093/0195166558.001.0001}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/191044640|title=Bourgeois Hinduism, or the faith of the modern Vedantists : rare discourses from early Colonial Bengal|last=Hatch|first=Brian A.|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2008|isbn=9780195326086|location=New York|pages=|oclc=191044640}} These claims base their assumptions on the lack of a unified Hindu identity prior to the [[Colonial India|colonial period]],{{Cite journal|last=Sarma|first=Deepak|date=2006-04-01|title=Hindu Leaders in North America?|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-9647.2006.00272.x/abstract|journal=Teaching Theology & Religion|language=en|volume=9|issue=2|pages=116|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9647.2006.00272.x|issn=1467-9647|via=}} and modern Hinduism's unprecedented outward focus on a [[Monotheism|monotheistic]] [[Vedanta]] worldview.{{Cite journal|last=Bayly|first=C. A.|date=2010|title=INDIA, THE BHAGAVAD GITA AND THE WORLD|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/modern-intellectual-history/article/india-the-bhagavad-gita-and-the-world/17B8BB3B1C73B98FEB166DEC9CF49111|journal=Modern Intellectual History|volume=7|issue=2|pages=282|doi=10.1017/s1479244310000077|issn=1479-2451|via=}} These developments have been read as the result of colonial prejudices which discouraged aspects of Indian religions which differed too greatly from the template of Christianity.{{Cite journal|last=Yelle|first=Robert A.|date=2005-04-01|title=Christians and Missionaries in India: Cross-Cultural Communication since 1500. Edited by Eric Frykenberg (Grand Rapids, Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Co., 2003) 419 pp. $39.00|url=http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/10.1162/002219505323383059|journal=The Journal of Interdisciplinary History|volume=35|issue=4|pages=681–682|doi=10.1162/002219505323383059|issn=0022-1953}} It has been noted that the prominence of the [[Bhagavad Gita]] as a primary religious text in Hindu discourse was a historical response to colonial criticisms of Indian culture. Europeans found that the Gita had more in common with their own Christian Bible, leading to the denouncement of Hindu practices more distantly related to monotheistic world views; with native subjects continually characterizing their faith as the equal of Christianity in belief (more clear monotheism) and structure (providing an equivalent primary sacred text).{{Cite journal|last=Longkumer|first=Arkotong|date=2017-04-03|title=The power of persuasion: Hindutva, Christianity, and the discourse of religion and culture in Northeast India|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/0048721X.2016.1256845|journal=Religion|volume=47|issue=2|pages=203–227|doi=10.1080/0048721x.2016.1256845|issn=0048-721X}} [[Hindu nationalism]] developed in the 19th century as an internalization of European ideological domination; with local elites aiming to make themselves and Indian society modern by "emulating the West".{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/368365428|title=Hindu Nationalism : A Reader|last=Jaffrelot|first=Christophe.|date=2007|publisher=Princeton University Press|others=|year=|isbn=9780691130972|location=Princeton, N.J.|pages=6–7|oclc=368365428}} This led to the emergence of what some have called [[Neo-Hinduism|'neo-Hinduism':]]{{Cite journal|last=Battaglia|first=Gino|date=2017-10-03|title=Neo-Hindu Fundamentalism Challenging the Secular and Pluralistic Indian State|url=http://www.mdpi.com/2077-1444/8/10/216|journal=Religions|language=en|volume=8|issue=10|pages=216|doi=10.3390/rel8100216}} consisting of reformist rhetoric transforming Hindu tradition from above, disguised as a revivalist call to return to the [[Historical Vedic religion|untainted origins of the faith]]. Reflecting the same arguments made by Christian missionaries, who argued that the more superstitious elements of Hindu practice were responsible for corrupting the potential rational philosophy of the faith (i.e. the more Christian-like sentiments).{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/368365428|title=Hindu Nationalism : A reader|last=Jaffrelot|first=Christophe.|date=2007|publisher=Princeton University Press|others=|year=|isbn=9780691130972|location=Princeton, N.J.|pages=7|oclc=368365428}} Moving the definitions of Hindu practice away from more overt idol worshiping, reemphasizing the concept of [[Brahman]] as a monotheistic divinity, and focusing more on the figure of [[Krishna]] in [[Vaishnavism]] due to his role as a messianic type figure (more inline with European beliefs) which makes him a suitable alternative to the Christian figure of [[Jesus in Christianity|Jesus Christ.]]{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/191044640|title=Bourgeois Hinduism, or the faith of the modern Vedantists : rare discourses from early Colonial Bengal|last=Hatcher|first=Brian A.|date=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=0195326083|location=New York|pages=|oclc=191044640}} [[File:Kerala Raksha Yatra - BJP - 2011.jpg|left|thumb|BJP supporters march in [[Kerala]].]] The [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] (BJP), India's current ruling party, follows this tradition of nationalistic Hinduism ([[Hindutva]]), and promotes an Indian national identity infused with [[Neo-Vedanta|neo-Vedantic]] thought influenced by this historical colonial mentality.{{Cite journal|last=Harriss|first=John|date=2015-10-02|title=Hindu Nationalism in Action: The Bharatiya Janata Party and Indian Politics|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/00856401.2015.1089826|journal=South Asia: Journal of South Asian Studies|volume=38|issue=4|pages=712–718|doi=10.1080/00856401.2015.1089826|issn=0085-6401}}{{Cite journal|last=Singh|first=Jan|date=2015|title=India's Right Turn|url=https://read-dukeupress-edu.proxy.library.carleton.ca/world-policy-journal|journal=World Policy Journal|volume=32 |issue=2|pages=93|via=}} Critics have claimed that British writer [[Rudyard Kipling]]'s portrayals of Indian characters in his works generally supported the colonialist view that colonized people were incapable of surviving without the help of [[Europe]]ans, describing these portrayals as [[racist]].{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/443889.stm | work=BBC News | title=Kipling comes under review | date=10 September 1999 | accessdate=2010-04-30}} In his famous poem "[[The White Man's Burden]]", Kipling directly makes this point by romanticizing British colonialism in India and elsewhere in the world.{{Cite journal|last=Brantlinger|first=Patrick|date=2007|title=Kipling's "The White Man's Burden" and Its Afterlives|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/209518|journal=English Literature in Transition, 1880-1920|volume=50|issue=2|pages=172–191|doi=10.1353/elt.2007.0017|issn=1559-2715}}{{Cite journal|last=Brantlinger|first=Patrick|date=2005|title=The Complexity of Kipling's Imperialist Politics|url=http://muse.jhu.edu.proxy.library.carleton.ca/article/366432/pdf|journal=English Literature in Transition, 1880-1920|volume=48 |issue=1|pages=88|via=}} Kipling's poem idolizes Western culture as entirely rational and civilized, while treating non-white cultures as 'childlike' and 'demonic'.{{Cite journal|last=Syed|first=Jawad|last2=Ali|first2=Faiza|date=2011-03-01|title=The White Woman's Burden: from colonial civilisation to Third World development|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/01436597.2011.560473|journal=Third World Quarterly|volume=32|issue=2|pages=349–365|doi=10.1080/01436597.2011.560473|issn=0143-6597}} Similar sentiments have been interpreted in Kipling's other works. Notably defending the [[Second Boer War|Second Anglo-Boer War]] as a "white man's war";{{Cite journal|last=Free|first=Melissa|date=2016|title=Fault Lines of Loyalty: Kipling's Boer War Conflict|jstor=10.2979/victorianstudies.58.2.12|journal=Victorian Studies|volume=58|issue=2|pages=314|doi=10.2979/victorianstudies.58.2.12|via=}} presenting 'whiteness' as a morally and culturally superior trait of the West, and using it as a legitimizing for British colonial expansion and rule.{{Cite journal|last=Mondal|first=Sharleen|date=2014|title=WHITENESS, MISCEGENATION, AND ANTI-COLONIAL REBELLION IN RUDYARD KIPLING’S THE MAN WHO WOULD BE KING|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/victorian-literature-and-culture/article/whiteness-miscegenation-and-anticolonial-rebellion-in-rudyard-kiplings-the-man-who-would-be-king/91FEB2B55B2A8FD53713092881F1C00A|journal=Victorian Literature and Culture|volume=42|issue=4|pages=733–751|doi=10.1017/s1060150314000278|issn=1060-1503|via=}} His portrayal of Indians in his [[The Jungle Book|Jungle Book]] stories have also been criticized as examples of the [[Chauvinism|chauvinisti]]c [[infantilization]] of colonized peoples in [[popular culture]].{{Cite journal|last=Hotchkiss|first=Jane|date=2001|title=THE JUNGLE OF EDEN: KIPLING, WOLF BOYS, AND THE COLONIAL IMAGINATION|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/victorian-literature-and-culture/article/jungle-of-eden-kipling-wolf-boys-and-the-colonial-imagination/1C7BFF21148EA32F2AE6D51E6CB9F463|journal=Victorian Literature and Culture|volume=29|issue=2|pages=435–449|doi=10.1017/s1060150301002108|issn=1470-1553|via=}} Generally, fiction, such as Kipling's works, have contributed towards colonial mentality in the ways that the colonized people in these fictional narratives are made submissive to and dependent on white colonizers.{{Cite journal|last=Lee|first=Jonathan Rey|date=2012-11-01|title=When Lions Talk: Wittgenstein, Kipling, and the Language of Colonialism1|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1741-4113.2012.00916.x/abstract|journal=Literature Compass|language=en|volume=9|issue=11|pages=884–893|doi=10.1111/j.1741-4113.2012.00916.x|issn=1741-4113}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/54666707|title=White skins/Black masks : representation and colonialism|last=1960-|first=Low, Gail Ching-Liang,|date=1996|publisher=Routledge|year=|isbn=0203359607|location=London|pages=1–10|oclc=54666707}} Individuals of Indian ancestry who adopt European culture, internalizing these colonial prejudices, have sometimes been labeled "Macaulay's Children". The term is usually used in a derogatory fashion, connoting disloyalty to India. It derives from 19th century British historian, politician, and colonial administrator [[Thomas Macaulay]], who regarded [[British culture]] as superior to Indian culture and who famously argued in favor of replacing Indian languages/dialects with [[English language|English]] as the medium of instruction in educational institutions.{{cite web|url=http://www.columbia.edu/itc/mealac/pritchett/00generallinks/macaulay/txt_minute_education_1835.html|title=Minute on Education (1835) by Thomas Babington Macaulay|last=Pritchett|first=Frances|publisher=}}{{Cite journal|last=Evans|first=Stephen|date=2002-09-01|title=Macaulay's Minute Revisited: Colonial Language Policy in Nineteenth-century India|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/01434630208666469|journal=Journal of Multilingual and Multicultural Development|volume=23|issue=4|pages=260–281|doi=10.1080/01434630208666469|issn=0143-4632}} The consequences of this development can still be felt in contemporary India, where the use of English, as opposed to [[Hindi]], still carries with it a level of superiority.{{Cite journal|last=Prasad|first=G. J. V.|date=2006|title=A Minute Stretching into Centuries: Macaulay, English, and India|url=http://go.galegroup.com.proxy.library.carleton.ca/ps/i.do?p=AONE&u=ocul_carleton&id=GALE|A208109729&v=2.1&it=r&sid=summon&authCount=1|journal=Nineteenth Century Prose|volume=33 |issue=2|pages=175|via=}} Nationalist politicians have campaigned and pushed forward policy changes to promote Hindi official use in education and media over English.{{Cite journal|last=Chand|first=Vineeta|date=2011-02-01|title=Elite positionings towards Hindi: Language policies, political stances and language competence in India1|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-9841.2010.00465.x/abstract|journal=Journal of Sociolinguistics|language=en|volume=15|issue=1|pages=6–35|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9841.2010.00465.x|issn=1467-9841}} ==Spanish Empire== In the colonial territories administered by the [[Spanish Empire]], [[Miscegenation|racial mixing]] between Spaniard settlers and the [[indigenous peoples]] resulted in the restrictive racial classes, like [[mestizo]], which promoted Spanish cultural hegemony and restricted '[[Other (philosophy)#Imperialism and colonialism|Otherness]]' within these colonized societies.{{Cite journal|last=Mangan|first=Jane E.|date=2013|title=Moving Mestizos in Sixteenth-Century Peru: Spanish Fathers, Indigenous Mothers, and the Children In Between|jstor=10.5309/willmaryquar.70.2.0273|journal=The William and Mary Quarterly|volume=70|issue=2|pages=273–294|doi=10.5309/willmaryquar.70.2.0273}}{{Cite journal|last=Zuniqa|first=Jean-Paul|date=1999|title=The Power of Blood: From Mestizo to the Idea of Race Mixture in Spanish Colonial America|url=|journal=Annales|volume=54 |issue=2|pages=425|via=}} [[File:Spanish_Empire_-_1824.jpg|left|thumb| Spanish Empire, 1824 ]]Mestizos and other mixed raced combinations were categorized into different [[casta]]s by colonial administrators as a means of maintaining Spanish dominance over the majority. This system was applied to Spanish colonies in the [[New Spain|Americas]] and the [[Spanish Philippines|Philippines]], where large populations of mixed raced individuals made up the increasing majority of the colonized population.{{Cite journal|last=Olson|first=Christa|date=2009-10-16|title=Casta Painting and the Rhetorical Body|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/02773940902991429|journal=Rhetoric Society Quarterly|volume=39|issue=4|pages=307–330|doi=10.1080/02773940902991429|issn=0277-3945}}{{Cite journal|last=Lentz|first=Mark|date=2017-02-01|title=Castas, Creoles, and the Rise of a Maya Lingua Franca in Eighteenth-Century Yucatan|url=https://read.dukeupress.edu/hahr/article-abstract/97/1/29/36780/Castas-Creoles-and-the-Rise-of-a-Maya-Lingua|journal=Hispanic American Historical Review|volume=97|issue=1|pages=29–61|doi=10.1215/00182168-3727376|issn=0018-2168}}[[File:Casta painting all.jpg|thumb|Casta painting showing couples of different races arranged hierarchically, and the resulting racial status of their children. ]] These racial categories punished those with [[Black African]], [[Afro-Latinos|Afro-Latin]], or ''[[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|indígenas]]'' (natives) heritage specifically. With those of European descent given privilege over these other mixtures. As a result of this system, Mestizos struggled to downplay their indigenous heritage and cultural trappings, in order to appear superficially more Spanish.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/957615716|title=Playing in the cathedral : music, race, and status in New Spain|last=Ramos-Kittrell|first=Jesús A.|isbn=0190236833|location=New York, NY|oclc=957615716}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/466659990|title=Maya or mestizo? : nationalism, modernity, and its discontents|last=Ronald.|first=Loewe,|date=2011|publisher=University of Toronto Press|year=|isbn=9781442601420|location=Toronto|pages=1–5|oclc=466659990}} With these internalized prejudices individuals' choices of clothes, occupations, and forms of religious expression.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/664565692|title=Indians and mestizos in the "lettered city" : reshaping justice, social hierarchy, and political culture in colonial Peru|last=1954-|first=Dueñas, Alcira,|date=2010|publisher=University Press of Colorado|isbn=9781607320197|location=Boulder, Colo.|oclc=664565692}} Those of mixed racial identities who wanted to receive the institutional benefits of being Spanish (such as higher educational institutions and career opportunities), could do so by suppressing their own cultures and acting with "Spanishness".{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/933580544|title=Playing in the cathedral : music, race, and status in New Spain|last=Ramos-Kittrell|first=Jesús A.|publisher=|year=|isbn=9780190236816|location=New York, NY|pages=37–38|oclc=933580544}} This mentality lead to commonplace racial forgery in Latin America, often accompanied by legitimizing oral accounts of a Spanish ancestor and a Spanish surname. Most mixed-white and white people in Latin America have Spanish surnames inherited from Spanish ancestors, while most other Latin Americans who have Spanish names and surnames acquired them through the [[Christianization]] and [[Hispanicization]] of the indigenous and African slave populations by Spanish friars.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/58525?tid=relatedcl|title=Y Tu Black Mama Tambien|last=Quinonez|first=Ernesto|date=19 June 2003|accessdate=2008-05-02}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/06360/748295-51.stm|title=Documentary, Studies Renew Debate About Skin Color's Impact|date=26 December 2006|accessdate=9 August 2010|publisher=Pittsburgh Post Gazette}}{{Cite news|url=http://newsblogs.chicagotribune.com/race/2009/02/in-many-different-cultures-and-countries-around-the-world-skin-color-plays-a-huge-role-in-the-concept-of-beauty-lighter-ski/comments/page/2/|title=Is Light Skin Still Preferable to Dark?|date=26 February 2010|accessdate=9 August 2010|publisher=[[Chicago Tribune]]}} In this heavily racial segregated context, the [[encomienda]] system was put in place. Under this system, entire native communities could be used as forced labor under the guise of collecting tribute. A means of rewarding notable soldiers or colonial officials with colonial possessions, as well as extorting native resources with free indigenous labor.{{Cite journal|last=Batchelder|first=Ronald W.|last2=Sanchez|first2=Nicolas|date=2013-07-01|title=The encomienda and the optimizing imperialist: an interpretation of Spanish imperialism in the Americas|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11127-012-9953-9|journal=Public Choice|language=en|volume=156|issue=1-2|pages=45–60|doi=10.1007/s11127-012-9953-9|issn=0048-5829}} Eventually, some Spaniards openly objected to the [[encomienda]] system, notably [[Bartolomé de Las Casas]], who insisted that the American ''indígenas'' were [[human being]]s with [[soul]]s and [[rights]] and were, in the words of [[Queen Isabella I]], "to be treated with justice and fairness".{{cite web|url=http://womenshistory.about.com/cs/medrenqueens/p/p_isabella_i.htm|title=Queen Isabella: More Than Just a Patron of Columbus|publisher=}} Historically, the religious identities of natives were targeted and suppressed by colonial authorities for Christian conversion.{{Cite journal|last=Murry|first=Gregory|date=2013-05-16|title="Tears of the Indians" or Superficial Conversion?: José de Acosta, the Black Legend, and Spanish Evangelization in the New World|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/507380|journal=The Catholic Historical Review|volume=99|issue=1|pages=29–51|doi=10.1353/cat.2013.0017|issn=1534-0708}} The [[Spaniard]]s were committed to converting their Amerindian subjects to [[Roman Catholicism]], and were quick to purge any native cultural practices that hindered this end.{{Cite journal|last=Wagner|first=E. Logan|date=2014-01-01|title=The Continuity of Sacred Urban Open Space: Facilitating the Indian Conversion to Catholicism in Mesoamerica|url=http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/15685292-01801005|journal=Religion and the Arts|volume=18|issue=1-2|pages=61–86|doi=10.1163/15685292-01801005|issn=1568-5292}} However, most initial attempts at this were only partially successful, as Amerindian groups simply blended Catholicism with their traditional beliefs.{{Cite journal|last=Ditchfield|first=Simon|date=2004-12-01|title=Of Dancing Cardinals and Mestizo Madonnas: Reconfiguring the History of Roman Catholicism in the Early Modern Period|url=http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/1570065043124011|journal=Journal of Early Modern History|volume=8|issue=3|pages=386–408|doi=10.1163/1570065043124011|issn=1570-0658}} [[Syncretism]] between native beliefs and Christianity is still largely prevalent in Indian and Mestizo communities in Latin America.{{Cite journal|last=Beatty|first=Andrew|date=2006-06-01|title=The Pope in Mexico: Syncretism in Public Ritual|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1525/aa.2006.108.2.324/abstract|journal=American Anthropologist|language=en|volume=108|issue=2|pages=324–335|doi=10.1525/aa.2006.108.2.324|issn=1548-1433}} On the other hand, the Spaniards did not impose their language to the degree they did their religion, and the [[Roman Catholic Church]] even evangelized in [[Quechua languages|Quechua]], [[Nahuatl]], [[Guarani languages|Guarani]], etc., contributing to the expansion of these Amerindian languages and equipping them with writing systems.{{cite web|url=http://www.voltairenet.org/article120716.html|title=Eliane Karp: pasado y presente, por Luis Arce Borja|first=Luis Arce Borja, Red|last=Voltaire|publisher=}} ===Philippines=== {{Main|Filipino mestizos}} Prior to colonization by the Spanish (1565-1898), the [[Sulu Archipelago]] (located in southern Philippines) was a colony of the [[Majapahit Empire]] (1293–1527) based in Indonesia. The Americans were the last country to colonize the [[Philippines]] (1898–1946) and nationalists claim that it continues to act as a [[neo-colony]] of the US despite its formal independence in 1946.{{Harvnb|Gómez Rivera|2000}}{{Harvnb|García|2009}} In the Philippines colonial mentality is most evident in the preference for [[Mestizo#Philippines|Filipino mestizos]] (primarily those of mixed [[Filipino people|native Filipino]] and [[white (people)|white]] ancestry, but also mixed indigenous Filipino and [[Chinese race|Chinese]], and other ethnic groups) in the entertainment industry and mass media, in which they have received extensive exposure despite constituting a small fraction of the population.{{cite web|url=http://www.americanchronicle.com/articles/viewArticle.asp?articleID=11261|title=Americanchronicle.com|publisher=}}{{cite web|title=Is the 'racist' BAYO advert real?|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/260881/scitech/socialmedia/is-the-racist-bayo-advert-real|work=6 June 2012|publisher=GMA News Online|accessdate=24 August 2013}}{{cite web|title=The semantics of 'mestizo'|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/267061/lifestyle/culture/the-semantics-of-mestizo|work=27 July 2012|publisher=GMA News|accessdate=24 August 2013}} The [[Spanish Constitution of 1812|Cádiz Constitution of 1812]] automatically gave [[Spanish nationality law|Spanish citizenship]] to all Filipinos regardless of race. The census of 1870 stated that at least one-third of the population of [[Luzon]] had partial Hispanic ancestry (from varying points of origin and ranging from [[Latin America]] to Spain).Jagor, Fëdor, et al. (1870). [http://www.authorama.com/former-philippines-b-8.html ''The Former Philippines thru Foreign Eyes''] The combined number of all types of white mestizos or Eurasians is 3.6%, according to a genetic study by [[Stanford University]].{{cite web |url=http://hpgl.stanford.edu/publications/AJHG_2001_v68_p432.pdf |title=A Predominantly Indigenous Paternal Heritage for the Austronesian-Speaking Peoples of Insular Southeast Asia and Oceania |accessdate=2008-02-20 |format=PDF |publisher=[[Stanford University]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100214223039/http://hpgl.stanford.edu/publications/AJHG_2001_v68_p432.pdf |archivedate=14 February 2010 |df=dmy }} This is contradicted by another genetic study done by California University which stated that Filipinos possess moderate amounts of European admixture.{{cite journal |url=http://www.genetics.org/content/early/2015/06/18/genetics.115.178616.full.pdf+html|author= *Institute for Human Genetics, University of California San Francisco |title= Self-identified East Asian nationalities correlated with genetic clustering, consistent with extensive endogamy. Individuals of mixed East Asian-European genetic ancestry were easily identified; we also observed a modest amount of European genetic ancestry in individuals self-identified as Filipinos|journal= Genetics Online|publisher= |year=2015|volume= |pages=1}} Evidence suggests that fair skin was a characteristic of the cloistered ''[[binukot]]'', who were often kept indoors from a very early age. In historical epics of the Philippines their fair skin was presented as a standard of beauty among the upper class.{{Harvnb|Abrera|2008-2009}} Some cite this as proof that desire for light-colored skin predates colonial influences. One of the more adverse physical consequences in the idealization and acceptance of colonial mentality can be seen in the high rate of consumer demand for [[skin bleaching]] products used by some indigenous women and a smaller percentage of indigenous men and dark-skinned mestizas and mestizos, in the Philippines.Counter, S. Allen, [http://www.boston.com/news/globe/health_science/articles/2003/12/16/whitening_skin_can_be_deadly/ Whitening skin can be deadly], [[Boston Globe]], 16 December 2003 Demand in the Philippines and in some other tropical countries continue to be widespread.{{cite web|url=http://www3.niu.edu/ptaa/beauty_in_me.htm|title=The Beauty In Me|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715193304/http://www3.niu.edu/ptaa/beauty_in_me.htm|archivedate=15 July 2007|df=dmy-all}} ==See also== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[Acculturation]] **[[:Category:History of colonialism|Category: History of colonialism]] *[[Colonialism]] *[[Colorism]] *[[Creolization]] *[[Cultural assimilation]] *[[Cultural cringe]] *[[Cultural identity]] *[[Cultural imperialism]] *[[Decreolization]] *[[Enculturation]] *[[Globalization]] *[[Hamitic#Hamitic theory as an ideology within colonialism|Hamitic theory]] *[[Hellenization]] **[[History of colonialism]] *[[Impact of Western European colonialism and colonisation]] *[[Intercultural competence]] *[[Language shift]] *[[Thomas Macaulay#India|Macaulay's minutes]] *[[Melting pot]] *[[Mongrel complex]] *[[Paper Bag Party]] *[[Passing (racial identity)]] *[[Race (classification of human beings)|Race]] *[[Racialism]] *[[Romanization (cultural)]] *[[Self-fulfilling prophecy]] *[[Social interpretations of race]] *[[Syncretism]] *[[Westernization]] }} == References == {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== {{Refbegin|indent=yes}} : {{citation |last=Abrera |first=María Bernadette L. |title=Seclusion and Veiling of Women: A Historical and Cultural Approach |url=http://journals.upd.edu.ph/index.php/pssr/article/viewFile/1274/1630 |journal=Philippine Social Sciences Review |date=January–December 2008–2009 |volume=60-61 |series=1-2 |publisher=College of Social Sciences and Philosophy, [[University of the Philippines Diliman]], U.P. Diliman Journals Online |location=Quezon City, Philippines |pages=34–56 |issn=0031-7802 |oclc=5657379 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s8suti6f?url=http://journals.upd.edu.ph/index.php/pssr/article/viewFile/1274/1630 |archivedate=21 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} : {{citation |last=García |first=José Miguel |title=The North American Invasion Continues |url=http://jmgpatria.blogspot.com/2009/06/american-invasion-continues_7055.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sUj78U8A?url=http://jmgpatria.blogspot.com/2009/06/american-invasion-continues_7055.html |archivedate=4 September 2010 |accessdate=5 September 2010 |date=30 June 2009 |work=Patria Philippines, at the Recovery of Our Inherited Archipelago |publisher=Blogger by [[Google]] |location=San Francisco, California, United States of America |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} : {{citation |last=Gómez Rivera |first=Guillermo |authorlink=Guillermo Gómez Rivera |title=The Filipino State |url=http://www.buscoenlaces.es/kaibigankastila/rivera3.html |date=20 September 2000 |publisher=Buscoenlaces |location=Spain |at=CHAPTER VI 1900s: The Filipino People was Deprived of its Own State |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rkiPPhc9?url=http://www.buscoenlaces.es/kaibigankastila/rivera3.html |archivedate=5 August 2010 |accessdate=5 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} : {{citation |last=Perdón |first=Renato |title=Footnotes to Philippine History |url=https://books.google.com/?id=vqKsKUUSNNQC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |year=2010 |publisher=[[Universal Publishers (USA)|Universal-Publishers]] |location=Boca Ratón, Florida, United States of America |isbn=1-59942-842-3 |pages=268 }} : {{citation |last1=Schirmer |first1=Daniel B. |authorlink= |last2=Shalom |first2=Stephen Rosskamm |author2-link=Stephen Shalom |title=The Philippines Reader: A History of Colonialism, Neocolonialism, Dictatorship, and Resistance |url=https://books.google.com/?id=TXE73VWcsEEC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |edition=illustrated, 1st |year=1987 |publisher=[[South End Press]] |location=Cambridge, Massachusetts, United States of America |isbn=0-89608-275-X |oclc=14214735 |pages=425 }} {{Refend}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Colonial Mentality}} [[Category:Colonialism|Mentality]] [[Category:Cultural revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} '''Communist crimes''' ({{lang-pl|zbrodnie komunistyczne}}), is a legal definition used in [[Polish Penal Code|Polish criminal law]].
The concept of a communist crime is also used more broadly internationally, and is employed by human rights NGOs as well as government agencies such as the [[Unitas Foundation]], the [[Institute for Information on the Crimes of Communism]], the [[Institute for the Study of Totalitarian Regimes]], the [[Institute for the Investigation of Communist Crimes in Romania]] and the [[Office for the Documentation and the Investigation of the Crimes of Communism]].
==Polish law== In legal terminology – as defined by the Article 2.1 of [[Dziennik Ustaw|the Journal of Laws]] (Dziennik Ustaw, DzU) of the [[Republic of Poland]] issued 18 December 1998,<ref name="ustawa-2.2" /> "Communist crimes" constitute crimes committed by the functionaries of the [[communist state|Communist]] apparatus between [[Soviet invasion of Poland (1939)|17 September 1939 (Soviet invasion of Poland)]] and [[Fall of communism in Poland|31 December 1989 (fall of Communism)]]. The crimes defined therein form either [[political repression]] or direct violation of [[human rights]] of an individual or a group; including those, otherwise named in Polish [[criminal law]] of that particular time. The concept also covers several other illegal activities prohibited by Polish laws already in place since 1932, such as [[False document|falsification of documents]] and using them with the intent to cause harm to people mentioned in them.<ref name="ustawa-2.1">{{cite web|url= http://www.ipn.gov.pl/download.php?s=1&id=7968 |title=Ustawa z dnia 18 grudnia 1998 r. o Instytucie Pamięci Narodowej - Komisji Ścigania Zbrodni przeciwko Narodowi Polskiemu }} {{small|(299 KB)}}. Art. 2.1. . Retrieved as of 8 May 2007.</ref>
The concept of Communist crimes was legally introduced in 1998 and revised several times.<ref name="ustawa-nagłówek">''Ustawa..'', see headings of document for list of legal acts published in [[Dziennik Ustaw]] modyfing the original document</ref> It was designed to facilitate studies of events and [[prosecution]] of people in [[authority]] who committed crimes against Polish citizens as well as the Polish state.<ref name="others">The concept of a communist crime is also applicable if the victim was not a Polish citizen but was wronged on Polish territory.</ref> The definition is conceptually similar to the legal concept of a [[Nazi crime]].<ref name="GenRaj">{{cite journal|last=Rajman|first=Genowefa|url=http://www.prawo.lex.pl/czasopisma/wpp/zb_komunist.html|title=Zbrodnie Komunistyczne w koncepcji Polskiego prawa karnego|trans-title=Communist crimes in the concept of Polish criminal law|language=pl|journal=Military Legal Review|publisher=prawo.lex.pl|year=2006|issue=1|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070125053236/http://www.prawo.lex.pl/czasopisma/wpp/zb_komunist.html|archivedate=25 January 2007}}</ref>
===Articles 4 to 7=== A functionary of a Communist state is defined as a [[public official]] including those who received legal protection similar to public officials, particularly government officials and leaders of the [[Communist Party]].<ref name="ustawa-2.2">''Ustawa..'', Art. 2.2.</ref> The functionaries involved would most likely work for [[History of Polish Intelligence Services|Polish intelligence]], [[Milicja Obywatelska|security service]] and other internal affairs (particularly [[censorship]] and religious affairs) departments. Particular organizations named as examples include [[Ministry of Public Security of Poland]], [[Służba Bezpieczeństwa]] and [[Główny Zarząd Informacji Wojska Polskiego]].<ref name="ustawa-5.1">''Ustawa..'', Art. 5.1.</ref> The communist crimes could have also been committed in Poland by members of foreign civil or military services,<ref name="ustawa-5.2">''Ustawa..'', Art. 5.2.</ref> such as the [[KGB]], [[NKVD]], [[SMERSH]], and [[Stasi]].
Crimes, recognized by [[international law]] as [[crimes against humanity]], [[crimes against peace]] and [[war crimes]], are not affected by the [[statute of limitations]] in Poland. Those crimes are not affected either by the former [[amnesty]] or abolition decrees issued in Communist Poland before 7 December 1989.<ref name="ustawa-4.3">''Ustawa..'', Art. 4.3.</ref> In case of murders, the Polish statute of limitations begins on 1 August 1990 and runs for 40 years, and for 30 years for other crimes.<ref name="ustawa-4.1">''Ustawa..'', Art. 4.1.</ref><ref name="ustawa-4.1"/>
The concept has replaced the term [[Stalinism|Stalinist crime]] (''zbrodnia stalinowska'') previously used in Polish law for similar acts,<ref name="GenRaj"/> just as the concept of [[Nazi crime]] has replaced that of the [[Hitler]]ite crime. Both ''Stalinist'' and ''Hitlerite'' crimes were first defined by Polish legislation in 1991.<ref name="Witold Kulesza">{{cite web|url=http://www.senat.gov.pl/k4/dok/sten/032-t/321g.htm|title=32. posiedzenie Senatu RP, część 1 stenogramu: Witold Kulesza|trans-title=32nd Senate Meeting of the Republic of Poland, part 1 of the transcript: Witold Kulesza|language=pl|publisher=senat.gov.pl|accessdate=8 May 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930194416/http://www.senat.gov.pl/k4/dok/sten/032-t/321g.htm|archivedate=30 September 2007}}</ref>
While drafting the concept of the communist crime, Polish legislators specifically discarded the notion that a Communist crime is equal to a Nazi crime, or that the legislation of the communist crime can be based on that of the Nazi crime (already defined in legislation of 31 August 1944), as while similar on some levels they are different enough on others to make [[Analogy#Law|analogies]] unacceptable.<ref name="GenRaj"/>
Communist crimes are primarily investigated by the [[Institute of National Remembrance]], a special [[research institute]] with [[prosecution]] powers, created by the same legislation that defined the concept of the Communist crime in 1998. Two examples of such unsolved Communist crimes are the [[Augustów chase]], and [[Kąkolewnica massacre]], also known as the Baran Forest Massacre.
==See also== * [[Decommunization]] * [[Lustration in Poland]] * [[The Black Book of Communism]] * [[People's Republic of Poland]] * [[Thick line]] (''gruba kreska'')
== Sources == * [http://www.communistcrimes.org Communist Crimes (hosted by the Unitas Foundation)] * [http://www.doomedsoldiers.com/kakolewnica-forest-masacre-little-katyn.html Kakolewnica Forest Massacre] * [http://www.doomedsoldiers.com/not-only-katyn-before-they-came.html "Not Only Katyn" by Ireneusz Sewastianowicz and Stanisław Kulikowski] * [http://www.doomedsoldiers.com/augustow-roundup.html The Augustow Roundup] * [http://www.ocnus.net/artman2/publish/Research_11/Hitler-vs-Stalin-Who-Killed-More.shtml Hitler vs. Stalin: Who Killed More? by Timothy Snyder]
==Notes and references== {{Reflist|2}}
