{{redirect|Teapot Dome}} [[File:Edward Doheny Testifying 2 crop.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Oil businessman Edward L. Doheny (at table, second from right) testifying before the Senate committee investigating the Teapot Dome oil leases, 1924]]
The '''"Teapot Dome scandal"''' was a bribery scandal involving the administration of United States President [[Warren G. Harding]] from 1921{{ndash}}1923. [[United States Secretary of the Interior|Secretary of the Interior]] [[Albert Bacon Fall]] had leased [[United States Navy|Navy]] [[petroleum]] reserves at [[Teapot Rock|Teapot Dome]] in [[Wyoming]], and two locations in [[California]], to private oil companies at low rates without competitive bidding. The leases were the subject of a sensational investigation by Senator [[Thomas J. Walsh]]. Convicted of accepting bribes from the oil companies, Fall became the first [[Cabinet of the United States|presidential cabinet]] member to go to prison; no one was convicted of paying the bribes.
Before the [[Watergate scandal]], Teapot Dome was regarded as the "greatest and most sensational scandal in the history of American politics".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gilderlehrman.org/historynow/historian5.php |title=Graft and Oil: How Teapot Dome Became the Greatest Political Scandal of its Time |last=Cherny |first=Robert W |work=History Now |publisher=[[Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History]] |accessdate=May 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100709015531/http://www.gilderlehrman.org/historynow/historian5.php |archivedate=July 9, 2010 |df= }}</ref> It damaged the reputation of the Harding administration, which was already severely diminished by its controversial handling of the [[Great Railroad Strike of 1922]] and Harding's veto of the [[World War Adjusted Compensation Act|Bonus Bill]] in 1922.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.presidentprofiles.com/Grant-Eisenhower/Warren-G-Harding-Domestic-and-foreign-affairs.html | title = Grant-Eisenhower | contribution = Warren G Harding: Domestic & foreign affairs | publisher = President profiles}}.</ref>
==History== [[File:Teapot Rock postcard crop.jpg|thumb|Teapot Dome around the time of the scandal, featuring Teapot Rock (from postcard ''circa'' 1922)]]
In the early 20th century, the U.S. Navy largely converted from [[coal]] to [[fuel oil]]. To ensure that the Navy would always have enough fuel available, several oil-producing areas were designated as naval oil reserves by [[William Howard Taft|President Taft]]. In 1921, President Harding issued an [[executive order]] that transferred control of [[Teapot Rock|Teapot Dome Oil Field]] in [[Natrona County, Wyoming]], and the [[Elk Hills Oil Field|Elk Hills]] and [[Buena Vista Oil Field]]s in [[Kern County, California]], from the [[United States Department of the Navy|Navy Department]] to the [[United States Department of the Interior|Department of the Interior]]. This was not implemented until 1922, when Interior Secretary Fall persuaded [[United States Secretary of the Navy|Navy Secretary]] [[Edwin Denby (politician)|Edwin C. Denby]] to transfer control.
Later in 1922, Interior Secretary Albert Fall leased the oil production rights at Teapot Dome to [[Harry Ford Sinclair|Harry F. Sinclair]] of Mammoth Oil, a subsidiary of [[Sinclair Oil Corporation]]. He also leased the Elk Hills reserve to [[Edward L. Doheny]] of [[Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company]]. Both leases were issued without competitive bidding. This manner of leasing was legal under the [[Mineral Leasing Act of 1920]].<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.blm.gov/pgdata/etc/medialib/blm/ut/vernal_fo/lands___minerals.Par.6287.File.dat/MineralLeasingAct1920.pdf | format=PDF | title= Mineral Leasing Act of 1920 as Amended (re-transcribed 2007-08-07) | publisher= Bureau of Land Management, U.S. Department of the Interior | accessdate=2014-09-08 }}</ref>
The lease terms were very favorable to the oil companies, which secretly made Fall a rich man. Fall had received a no-interest loan from Doheny of $100,000 (about ${{Format price|{{inflation|US|100000|1921}}}} today{{inflation-fn |US}}) in November 1921. He received other gifts from Doheny and Sinclair totaling about $404,000 (about ${{Format price|{{inflation|US|404000|1921}}}} today{{inflation-fn|US}}). This money changing hands was illegal, not the leases. Fall attempted to keep his actions secret, but the sudden improvement in his standard of living was suspect.
==Investigation and outcome== {{refimprove|section|date=April 2017}} In April 1922, a Wyoming oil operator wrote to Senator [[John B. Kendrick]], angered that Sinclair had been given a contract to the lands in a secret deal. Kendrick did not respond, but two days later on April 15, he introduced a resolution calling for an investigation of the deal.<ref>{{cite book | author = Davis, Margaret L | title= Dark Side of Fortune: Triumph and Scandal in the Life of Oil Tycoon Edward L. Doheny| publisher = University of California Press|year=2001|isbn=|page=149|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=q65CsgOv7dMC&pg=PA149}}</ref> [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Senator [[Robert M. La Follette Sr.]] of [[Wisconsin]] led an investigation by the Senate Committee on Public Lands. At first, La Follette believed Fall was innocent. However, his suspicions deepened after his own office in the Senate Office Building was ransacked.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/minute/Senate_Investigates_the_Teapot_Dome_Scandal.htm|title=Senate Investigates the "Teapot Dome" Scandal |work= Historical Minutes: 1921–1940|publisher=Art & History, United States Senate}}</ref>
[[File:Albert B. Fall with map background.jpg|thumb|[[Albert B. Fall]] was the first U.S. cabinet official sentenced to prison.]]
Democrat [[Thomas J. Walsh]] of [[Montana]], the most junior minority member, led a lengthy inquiry. For two years, Walsh pushed forward while Fall stepped backward, covering his tracks as he went. No evidence of wrongdoing was initially uncovered, as the leases were legal enough, but records kept disappearing mysteriously. Fall had made the leases appear legitimate, but his acceptance of the money was his undoing. By 1924, the remaining unanswered question was how Fall had become so rich so quickly and easily.
Money from the bribes had gone to Fall's cattle ranch and investments in his business. Finally, as the investigation was winding down with Fall apparently innocent, Walsh uncovered a piece of evidence Fall had forgotten to cover up: Doheny's $100,000 loan to Fall.
This discovery broke open the scandal. Civil and criminal suits related to the scandal continued throughout the 1920s. In 1927, the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] ruled that the oil leases had been corruptly obtained. The Court invalidated the Elk Hills lease in February 1927, and the Teapot Dome lease in October. Both reserves were returned to the Navy.<ref name=revenues/>
In 1929, Albert Fall was found guilty of accepting bribes from Doheny. Conversely, in 1930, Edward L. Doheny was acquitted of paying bribes to Fall. Further, Doheny's corporation foreclosed on Fall's home in [[Tularosa Basin]], New Mexico, because of "unpaid loans" that turned out to be that same $100,000 bribe. Sinclair served six months in jail on a charge of [[jury tampering]].<ref>{{cite book |last=McCartney |first=Laton |title=The Teapot Dome Scandal: How Big Oil Bought the Harding White House and Tried to Steal the Country |location=New York |publisher=Random House |year=2008 |isbn=978-1-4000-6316-1 }}</ref>
Although Fall was to blame for this scandal, Harding's reputation was sullied because of his involvement with the wrong people. Evidence proving Fall's guilt only arose after Harding's death in 1923.<ref>{{cite book|last1=MacDonald|first1=Scott B.|last2=Hughes|first2=Jane E.|title=Separating Fools from Their Money: A History of American Financial Scandals|date=2007|publisher=Transaction|location=New Brunswick, N.J.|accessdate=1 December 2015}}</ref> This was not the first time that Fall's character had been called into question. He had been suspected of the 1896 murder of rival attorney and politician [[Albert Jennings Fountain]] and his eight-year-old son Henry at White Sands near Tularosa, as the Fountains rode home from a meeting at Fall's ranch.{{cn|date=December 2016}}
Another significant outcome was the Supreme Court's ruling in ''[[McGrain v. Daugherty]]'' (1927) which, for the first time, explicitly established that [[Congress of the United States|Congress]] had the power to compel testimony.<ref name="oyez">{{Cite web | title = McGrain v. Daugherty | publisher = Oyez.org | url = https://www.oyez.org/cases/1901-1939/1924/1924_28 | accessdate = 2 November 2010}}</ref>
The field was then idled for 49 years, but went back into production in 1976. After earning over $569 million in revenue having extracted {{convert|22|e6oilbbl|lk=in}} of oil over the previous 39 years, in February 2015, the [[United States Department of Energy|Department of Energy]] sold the oil field for $45 million to Stranded Oil Resources Corp.<ref name=revenues>[http://www.denverpost.com/2015/01/30/government-sells-scandalized-teapot-dome-oilfield-for-45-million Government sells scandalized Teapot Dome oilfield for $45 million], ''[[Denver Post]]'', [[Associated Press]]'', January 30, 2015. Retrieved 4 June 2017.</ref>
==See also== * [[Little Green House on K Street]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == {{Commons category}} * Bates, J. Leonard. ''The Origins of Teapot Dome''. Urbana, IL: University of Illinois Press, 1963. * Bennett, Leslie E. [http://academic.brooklyn.cuny.edu/history/johnson/teapotdome.htm "One Lesson From History: Appointment of Special Counsel and the Investigation of the Teapot Dome Scandal"]. Washington, D.C.: Brookings Institution, 1999. * Ise, John. ''The United States Oil Policy''. New Haven, CT: Yale University Press, 1926. * Murphy, Blakely M. (ed.) ''Conservation of Oil and Gas: A Legal History''. Chicago: Section of Mineral Law, American Bar Association, 1949. * [[Burl Noggle|Noggle, Burl]]. ''Teapot Dome: Oil and Politics in the 1920s''. Baton Rouge, LA: Louisiana State University Press, 1962. * Werner, M. R. and Starr, John. ''Teapot Dome''. New York: Viking Press, 1959.
{{US federal public corruption law}} {{US history}}

{{About|the abbreviation for reading, writing and arithmetic||Three Rs (disambiguation){{!}}Three Rs}}
'''The three Rs''' (as in the letter ''R'')<ref>[http://www.papert.org/articles/ObsoleteSkillSet.html Obsolete Skill Set: The 3 Rs — Literacy and Letteracy in the Media Ages]</ref> are [[basic skills]] taught in schools: [[Reading (process)|'''''r'''''eading]], [[Writing|w'''''r'''''iting]] and [[Arithmetic|a'''''r'''''ithmetic]]. The phrase appeared in print as a space-filler in "The Lady's Magazine" for 1818, although it is sometimes attributed to a speech given by [[Sir William Curtis, 1st Baronet|Sir William Curtis]], Member of Parliament, in about 1795, the publication [[John Limbird|The Mirror of Literature, Amusement, and Instruction]], Volume 5, casts doubt on this by noting "It has been very much the fashion amongst a class of persons to attribute to Sir W.C. certain bulls (which would be more in place from an alderman in Dublin), and also a vulgarity and arrogance of speech which are by no means consistent with his character and conduct.". <ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=tBc4AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA75&dq=%22reading,+writing+and+%27rithmetic%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=1000&as_maxm_is=1&as_maxy_is=1850&as_brr=4&ei=IbHzSqLMKZXokATMprHKBQ#v=onepage&q=%22reading%2C%20writing%20and%20%27rithmetic%22&f=false The Mirror of Literature Amusement and Instruction, Volume 5] by John Timbs, J. Limbered, 1825</ref> The skills themselves are alluded to in [[St. Augustine]]'s ''Confessions'': ''nam illas primas, ubi legere et scribere et numerare discitur'' 'for those first, where to read, and to write, and ciphering is being learned.' <ref>Chapter 13, Book 1, [http://faculty.georgetown.edu/jod/latinconf/1.html Faculty.georgetown.edu]</ref>. Ciphering translates differently and can be defined as transposing, arguing, reckoning, a secretive method of writing, or numerating. Since its original creation, many others have used the term to describe other triples.
==Origin and meaning== The phrase "the Three Rs" may have originated in a speech made by [[Sir William Curtis]] in 1795. but this origination is disputed in the publication The Mirror of Literature, Amusement, and Instruction, Volume 5.<ref>"[https://idioms.thefreedictionary.com/the+three+Rs the three Rs.]" ''idioms.thefreedictionary.com''. The American Heritage Dictionary of Idioms by Christine Ammer. 2003, 1997. The Christine Ammer 1992 Trust</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=tBc4AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA75&dq=%22reading,+writing+and+%27rithmetic%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=1000&as_maxm_is=1&as_maxy_is=1850&as_brr=4&ei=IbHzSqLMKZXokATMprHKBQ#v=onepage&q=%22reading%2C%20writing%20and%20%27rithmetic%22&f=false The Mirror of Literature Amusement and Instruction, Volume 5] by John Timbs, J. Limbered, 1825</ref> An extended modern version of the three Rs consists of the "functional skills of literacy, numeracy and [[Information and communications technology|ICT]]".<ref>[http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/educationandlearning/qualificationsexplained/dg_173874 Functional Skills]</ref>
There is an earlier reference to the skills of reading, writing, and arithmetic in [[Augustine of Hippo|St Augustine]]'s [[Confessions (Augustine)|''Confessions'']] (c. 397-401), though of course the words do not begin with 'R' in Latin.
==Etymology== {{refimprove|date=June 2018}}
The phrase 'the three Rs' is used because each word in the phrase has a strong ''R'' [[phoneme]] (sound) at the beginning. The term is ironic, since someone with rudimentary language education would know that two of the original words do not actually begin with the letter ''R''. The third ''R'' was more probably Reckoning, not as is more usually stated 'Rithmetic. Reckoning was a Victorian term for mental arithmetic and had been in use as such since the 14th century.{{cn|date=June 2018}} The educationalist [[Louis P. Bénézet]] preferred "to read", "to reason", "to recite", adding, "by reciting I did not mean giving back, verbatim, the words of the teacher or of the textbook. I meant speaking the English language."<ref>L. P. Benezet, "The Teaching of Arithmetic I, II, III: The Story of an Experiment," Journal of the National Education Association, Volume 24(8): 241-244 (November 1935)</ref>
In the United States, during the 17th century, the curriculum in the common (elementary) schools of the New England colonies was summed up as the "four Rs" - Reading, 'Riting, "Rithmetic", and Religion.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Slosson|first1=Edwin Emory|title=The American Spirit in Education: A Chronicle of Great Teachers, Volume 33|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zg0OAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA305&dq=Sisters+of+Charity+of+Saint+Augustine&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eO7YU8aoKNGRyAT5kYKIDg&ved=0CIIBELsFMBI#v=onepage&q=Sisters%20of%20Charity%20of%20Saint%20Augustine&f=false|website=Googe Books|publisher=Yale University Press|accessdate=30 July 2014}}</ref>
==Other uses== More recent meanings of "the Three Rs" are: * In the subject of [[CNC]] code generation by Edgecam Workflow: Rapid, Reliable, Repeatable * In the subject of [[sustainability]]: [[Reduce, reuse, recycle]] * In animal welfare principles in research: see [[The Three Rs (animals)]]: Replacement, Reduction, Refinement * (See also [[3R (disambiguation)|3R]].)
== See also == * [[Standards based education reform]] * [[Traditional education]] * [[Trivium (education)]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Three Rs, The}} [[Category:Education reform]] [[Category:English phrases]]

revision.text:
The case '''Vermont vs Hunt (1982)''' had two major outcomes. One was a ruling by the [[Vermont Supreme Court]] that [[side judge]]s had the right to vote on plea agreements. The second was a lengthy review of judges' conduct used to reach this conclusion. This resulted in the state Judicial Conduct Board bringing 24 formal charges against three Supreme Court judges.
==Background== The state accused Gordon Hunt of murdering a neighbor in 1982. His attorney attempted to plea bargain for a minimum sentence of ten years. The judge who heard the case, [[James L. Morse]], accepted the plea. Both side judges, including Jane Wheel, disagreed. They brought their objections to the Vermont Supreme Court and, in 1984, obtained a ruling in favor of the side judges' decision.
==Judicial conduct== Wheel was accused of exerting undue influence over three state Supreme Court justices, [[William C. Hill]], [[Thomas L. Hayes]], and [[Ernest W. Gibson III]], and there were intimations of an affair between Wheel and Hill, which they denied.{{sfn|"State Board Investigating Judge Wheel"|page=1}} Among the other allegations against Wheel, she was accused of threatening the [[Vermont Attorney General]], [[John J. Easton Jr.]], by suggesting she would undermine his 1984 candidacy for governor if he pursued the investigation.<ref name=c180718/> At one point in the investigation, Assistant Attorney General [[Brian L. Burgess]] punctured a hole in an office wall in order to eavesdrop on a conversation between Hill and [[Jeffrey Amestoy]], who had succeeded Easton as Attorney General, in order to determine whether Hill was attempting to unduly influence Amestoy.<ref name=c180718/> During the investigation and subsequent court proceedings, all five Vermont Supreme Court justices recused themselves, and their positions were filled by temporary judges.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.burlingtonfreepress.com/story/entertainment/2018/06/18/breach-trust-when-vermont-supreme-court-trial/701134002|title='Breach of Trust' - When the Vermont Supreme Court was on trial|website=burlingtonfreepress.com|accessdate=6 August 2018}}</ref>
==Resolution== In 1986 and 1987, Hill and two other justices, Hill, Hayes, and Gibson were accused of tailoring decisions to suit Wheel, and helping her cover up payroll padding. Wheel was accused of wielding undue influence over the three justices.{{sfn|"High Court Drops Charges Against Gibson"|page=1B}} Hayes died before the charges could be resolved, and charges against Gibson were dropped.{{sfn|"High Court Drops Charges Against Gibson"|page=1B}} Wheel was convicted on charges arising from the case.{{sfn|"Ex-Judge Wheel Gets Jail Term"|page=1}} Hill was found to have violated rules regarding judicial conduct, and opted to retire at the end of his second six-year term, rather than applying to remain on the court until age 70, Vermont's mandatory retirement age for judges.{{sfn|"Former Vermont Supreme Court Justice Found in Violation of Conduct Rules"}} His former colleagues banned him from serving as a judge again.<ref name=c180718>{{Cite news| first=Paul |last=Lefebvre |title=A look at a jaw-dropping judicial scandal |newspaper=The Chronicle |location=Barton, Vermont |pages= 1A |date=August 6, 2018 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Judicial misconduct]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External references== *{{Cite book |first = James L. |last = Dunn |title = Breach of Trust |publisher=Onion River Press| date = 2018|isbn=9-78-099764587-3}} *{{cite web|title=State v. Hunt |url=https://law.justia.com/cases/vermont/supreme-court/1988/85-235.html}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{Politics of Kazakhstan}} '''Vice President of Kazakhstan''' was a political position in [[Kazakhstan]] 1991–1996.
{|class="wikitable" !Name !Took office !Left office ! Notes |- |[[Erik Asanbayev]] |December 1991 |22 February 1996 |<ref>[https://books.google.fi/books?id=neKm1X6YPY0C&pg=PA70&dq=erik+asanbayev&hl=fi&sa=X&ei=F3Y-VcPBL4XlywO9rIDIAw&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=erik%20asanbayev&f=false]</ref> |}
President [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]] issued a decree on 22 February 1996 removing Erik Asanbayev from his post.
According to Article 48 in the constitution the presidential line of succession is now as follows:
*1) Chairman of the [[Senate of Kazakhstan]] *2) Chairman of the [[Majilis]] *3) The Prime Minister

page.title: Virginia Federation of Tea Party Patriots

revision.text:
The '''Virginia Federation of Tea Party Patriots''' is a state-level federation of local, republican groups within the [[Virginia|Commonwealth of Virginia]] adhering to the principles of the [[Tea Party movement]]. The Federation advocates strict adherence to the [[United States Constitution]] and the [[Constitution of Virginia|Constitution of the Commonwealth of Virginia]], as well as fiscal responsibility, [[Open government|transparent government]], and grassroots citizen engagement within the political process.<ref>[http://virginiateapartypatriots.com/mission-and-charter/ Mission | Virginia Tea Party Patriots<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
A prior leader of the Federation ran in the [[United States Senate election in Virginia, 2012|2012 Senate race]] against former governor [[George Allen (U.S. politician)|George Allen]].<ref>[http://www.roanoke.com/news/columns_and_blogs/blogs/blue_ridge_caucus/state-tea-party-leaders-back-radtke-in-senate-primary/article_5d6c890b-5841-596f-9947-0fc923436adb.html State Tea Party leaders back Radtke in Senate primary | Blue Ridge Caucus<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The Federation intensified its political efforts at its citizen lobby day on January 21, 2013.<ref>http://virginiateapartypatriots.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/Lobby-Day-agenda.pdf</ref> Following the end of the session, it released its 2013 legislative scorecard, ranking 140 members of the [[Virginia General Assembly]] on issues important to the Federation. [https://vtppf.org/scorecards/ Legislative scorecards] are available typically within 60 days of the close of each annual session.
==See also== *[[Tea Party Movement]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://vatp.org/ Virginia Tea Party Patriots Federation Website]
